title-group.article-title: Aerodynamic Test Results for a Wing-Mounted Turboprop Propulsion Installation

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1985 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: The paper provides an overview of the renewed interest in turboprop propulsion systems for future commercial transport designs. The potential operating cost advantage of advanced turboprop designs is shown relative to advanced turbofan designs. Critical technology items for the aerodynamic installation of turboprop propulsion systems are presented, along with experimental results addressing the main technology issue for wing-mounted turboprop installations. Nacelle installation effects are presented for overwing and underwing nacelles. The drag reduction for nacelle contouring is also shown. Wing/nacelle/power data are presented for the baseline wing geometry and for a wing modified to reduce the propeller power effects.

ref.mixed-citation: Welge, H. R., and Crowder, J. P., Simulated Propeller Slipstream Effects on a Supercritical Wing, Douglas Aircraft Company, NASA contract NAS2-9472, NASA CR-152138, June 1978.
Smith, R. C., and Levin, A. D., Propfan Installation Aerodynamics of a Supercritical Swept-Wing Trans- port Configuration, AIAA Report 81-1563, July 1981.
Vernon, D. F.; Page, G. S.; and Welge, H. R., Propfan Experimental Data Analysis, Douglas Aircraft Com- pany, NASA contract NAS2-11672, NASA CR-166582, June 1984.
